comment.author: 23885771@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/47290943@N03] Phone boxes were first introduced to the streets of Dublin in 1925 and quickly spread out across the county over the following decades. I think the type pictured above were made of reinforced cast-concrete.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: There's a picture of a phone box of this type here, including the Gaelic font P&T symbol.

comment.author: 23885771@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/58894288@N07] There's a nice pic of the very first type of Irish phonebox in Dawson Street, your web-link. Strange that I never noticed it before and will be sure to have a look next time I'm in that part of Dublin. All the best. Stuart.

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: www.britishtelephones.com/histuk.htm Before the telephone kiosk there was the public call office. 1884 - "They were at first located in 'silence cabinets' found in shops, railway stations and other public places." 1922 - "The telephone system in Southern Ireland was transferred to the Eireann Administration (then the Irish Free State); 194 telephone exchanges with 19,037 lines and 553 call offices passed into the control of the new administration." There is a humorous website about Irish phone boxes. www.irishcultureandcustoms.com/ALandmks/PhoneBoxes.html

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: The latest Irish telephone directory online from Ancestry is 1921 Belfast/Dublin/Cork. You have to be logged in to view. search.ancestry.co.uk/Browse/View.aspx?dbid=1025&path... Dublin and Cork Districts begin at image 310 Dublin District Manager was at Crown Alley & Temple Bar. Are any later Irish phone directories online? The 1932 directory would mention where the new-fangled telephone boxes were.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] Would it mention locations of the boxes in the 1932 directory? We have a fairly complete set of phone directories here at Library Towers...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: We can only hope that there was an article in the directory about the new service. The photo is from the Independent newspaper archive, so it should be on microfilm. www.nli.ie/en/newspapers-newsplan-project.aspx Talk about looking for a needle in a haystack...

comment.author: 59374653@N03
comment._content: One still stands in Foxrock Village, Dublin 18. Its classed as a listed building.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Here's the Foxrock box in Streetview. I have learned from the thread that it is called a K1 box.

comment.author: 47290943@N03

Thinking of starting a quickfire Flickr quiz every Friday to check that you're all paying attention!  :D

comment.author: 92117053@N04
comment._content: Looks like the corner of Westmorland St and Aston Quay. At side of the Old Ballast office which is now the Royal Liver Assurance building (Ballast House), in front of the door between the Londis window and Carrols shop is located

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/92117053@N04] I don't know. it's so hard to tell with the new frontage on the building. Is this where you mean?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 92117053@N04
comment._content:
Yes this correct location but no phone boxes in view so photo must be pre 1932,
I am looking for a more detailed photo to show the railings the best so far is a film
clip on the British Pathe. Com site (Eucharistic Congress 1932 A million people kneel
in worship best frames are 2:00 - 2:03. Thank you for posting  so many wonderfull
photos only came across them last week and as I am almost 80 have a lot to catch up on.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/92117053@N04] Crikey, I think you're right! Well done on finding the British Pathé film. This photo was taken around the Spring of 1932 and the phone boxes may well have been installed in preparation for the Eucharistic Congress, in which case this film you unearthed shows them when they were only a couple of months in situ.

I'll ask some of the others to have a look at the film and see what they think... Thanks again, and sure you've loads of time to catch up...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Hello everyone! Could you have a look at this from British Pathé: A Million People Kneel in Prayer please! See comments above from woodworker_34. He thinks the phone boxes were being installed outside the old Ballast House just on O'Connell Bridge, and I'm very much inclined to agree. The crucial time in this clip is around 2:00 to 2:03...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 92117053@N04
comment._content: After a close look at British Pathe clip (still 123) I note that the phone boxes are located between windows 3 and 4 and from left above windows 1,2 & 4 what look like wall vents can be seen with no vent over window 3. In photo of phone boxes window on left has a vent in same place and window at back of boxes has not the railings at back of phone boxes look the same height when you compare the two photos also had a look at photo (www.flickr.com/photos/combatcamera44/6080610789/) to check stonework and it looks the same in the two photos

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/92117053@N04] Thanks again! I'm happy enough. "Location Identified" tag now added, and I've placed it on our Flickr Map.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
